author: jgm
content:
There is a difference between "valid" and "verified".  Any op with a matching signature is valid, but unless it does what the user wants it to do it isn't verified.

Two separate sources of the signature would make sense, in that it would be about the only way to verify that the operation really was what it said it was.  But then we're in to explaining to users how to compare them, and would we need a third tool for that?

author: jgm
content: (Now <@755590043632140352> has got me thinking about how `ethdo` could be malicious.  One obvious way would be to put whatever the user said in the change op JSON, but to sign it for my fund-for-an-evil-hideout address.  When it comes to broadcast, `ethdo` would just swap out the address before sending the data to the beacon node and hey presto I have enough for my evil hideout.)

author: jgm
content: Yeah, `ethdo` is passed op saying "change validator X to credentials Y", `ethdo` signs "change validator X to credentials Z".  The signature would need to be independently verified to catch this (the JSON can say whatever it likes, `ethdo` will always broadcast the ops with credentials Z).

author: barnabasbusa
content: would you be able to generate a valid signature with a public key + (changed) withdrawal address only tho?

author: barnabasbusa
content: I thought the private key is used to generate the valid signature where the private key is used together with the given withdrawal address which then creates a unique signature that could not be spoofed if you don't have the private key available.\

author: jgm
content:
`ethdo` has the private key and is doing the signing.  All that happens is that in the code today where it signs `(validator index, new withdrawal credentials)` I swap out `new withdrawal credentials` for `evil withdrawal credentials generated by me`) and sign that instead.  The JSON will still look okay, but the signature won't verify if checked by a third party.  Which is where the third party to check the signature comes in to play.

(All this is assuming that I'm evil, which I hope isn't the case but totally appreciate that something this important shouldn't _rely_ on me not being evil.)

So: two different sources to generate the operations, and for non-technical users something with the ability to independently verify them, makes sense.
